lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can practise pronouncing words with the “ie”, “y”, and “igh” sounds accurately.
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Say: “high, fly, tie.” Students repeat and identify the spelling pattern. Sort into groups on the board: “-igh”, “-ie”, “-y”.
stretchStrategies: Students make a short “Weather Fact Card” about another country with 1 weather type, 1 location, and 1 “ie/igh/y” word. They share with a partner.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read a short text about weather around the world and find key details such as weather types and locations.
supportStrategies: (Reading) Read the text aloud in pairs. Students underline weather and place names. Then answer 3 comprehension questions.
stretchStrategies: Students make a short “Weather Fact Card” about another country with 1 weather type, 1 location, and 1 “ie/igh/y” word. They share with a partner.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can learn interesting facts about how weather is different in other parts of the world.
supportStrategies: (Science) Use a world map or globe. Say: “It’s snowy in Canada.” Students place sticky notes on the correct region and share what they know.
stretchStrategies: Students make a short “Weather Fact Card” about another country with 1 weather type, 1 location, and 1 “ie/igh/y” word. They share with a partner.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
